courseDescription: Study of selected topics in counseling.
Study of selected topics in counseling.

courseTitle: Principles of Professional Counseling and Ethics
courseDescription: Aligned with a spiral approach to learning, students will be introduced to theory, practice, methods, basic principles, and concepts used by counselors in educational settings and community agencies.  In subsequent courses, these topics will be revisited in depth.  The course will emphasize professional and ethical issues related to counseling.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing digital resources for counseling practice
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with clients and colleagues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of ethical dilemmas in counseling
Developing treatment plans based on client needs

courseDescription: A study of phase and stage theories of lifespan development with application to counseling.  Current research findings on major developmental issues (e.g., gender) will be emphasized.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of phase and stage theories of lifespan development
Application of counseling techniques based on developmental theories
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with clients of different ages
Empathy and active listening skills in counseling sessions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of research findings on developmental issues
Problem-solving in counseling scenarios based on developmental theories
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing client case files and progress tracking
Leadership in guiding clients through counseling process

courseDescription: The course focuses on development of attitudes and skills essential to effective professional counseling.  Emphasis is on conducting the helping interview, as well as conducting an intake interview, a mental status evaluation, a biopsychosocial history, a mental health history, and a psychological assessment for treatment planning and caseload management.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Active listening skills during counseling sessions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing mental health histories for treatment planning

courseTitle: Advanced Counseling and Psychotherapy Techniques, Crisis, and Trauma
courseDescription: This course provides an overview of advanced techniques used by counselors, including crisis and trauma response and the principles of trauma-informed care.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathy and rapport building with traumatized clients

courseDescription: This course is designed to prepare students to facilitate structured counseling groups for children and adolescents primarily in the K-12 school setting.   CACREP Required Content: GROUP WORK - studies that provide both theoretical and experiential understandings of group purpose, development, dynamics, theories, methods, skills, and other group approaches in a multicultural society, including all of the following: (a) principles of group dynamics, including group process components, developmental stage theories, group members' roles and behaviors, and therapeutic factors of group work; (b) group leadership or facilitation styles and approaches, including characteristics of various types of group leaders and leadership styles; (c) theories of group counseling, including commonalities, distinguishing characteristics, and pertinent research and literature; and (d) group counseling methods, including group counselor orientations and behaviors, appropriate selection criteria and methods, and methods of evaluation of effectiveness.  Students will be required to complete 30 hours of fieldwork with K-12 aged youth, preferably in a school setting.
Technical and Digital Skills: Facilitating structured counseling groups for children and adolescents
Fieldwork experience with K-12 aged youth
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding group members' roles and behaviors
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying group counselor orientations and behaviors
Evaluating the effectiveness of group counseling methods
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Developing group facilitation styles and approaches
Selecting appropriate counseling methods for groups
Managing fieldwork with K-12 aged youth

courseDescription: Developing effective group leadership competencies is the focus for the course.  Identification of group dynamics, use of group level process, and the self-development of the leader are some major topics.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication within a group setting
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Developing leadership competencies within a group

courseDescription: This course examines individual and group approaches to formal and informal assessment techniques, including diagnosis.  It includes an examination of: the history of assessment; basic test statistics; test worthiness (reliability, validity, and cross-cultural issues); the selection, administration, and interpretation of assessment instruments; and ethical and legal issues relative to assessment.  The focus of this class is on major concepts and principles of psychological testing and evaluation and use of standardized instruments with differing populations. Pre- or
Technical and Digital Skills: Ethical and legal issues in assessment
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Adhering to assessment standards and protocols

courseDescription: Examines the etiology, risk factors, assessment, counseling approaches and treatment of alcoholism and other addictions.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with clients dealing with addiction
Empathy and active listening skills in counseling
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Risk factor identification for addictive behaviors
Treatment planning for individuals with addiction issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination in addiction treatment programs

courseDescription: A study of major theories of counseling and psychotherapy.  The primary focus is on providing students with a theoretical foundation upon which to develop their own approach for providing counseling and psychotherapy.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding different counseling and psychotherapy techniques
Applying theoretical concepts to real-life scenarios
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing case studies to apply appropriate theories
Identifying effective strategies for different client needs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Developing personalized counseling plans for clients

courseTitle: Social and Cultural Issues in Counseling
courseDescription: Designed to engage helping professionals in cultural self-awareness and the search for solutions to disparities in society through counseling work.  Emphasis on the social identities of gender, race, ethnicity, religion, ability, class, sexual orientation, and age.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing technology for virtual counseling sessions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathy and active listening in counseling sessions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying systemic barriers in counseling practices
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Advocating for social justice in counseling

courseDescription: This internship is designed to provide individual students with a planned program of advanced on-the-job professional experience in a school setting. A university instructor will coordinate internship assignments. An experienced professional in the school setting will provide direct supervision. Available for pass/fail grading only. Completion of a background check is required prior to commencing the field placement.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data entry and management in school databases
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Providing guidance and support to students

courseDescription: This supervised experience will enable students to practice basic and intermediate individual and group counseling skills with clients while integrating knowledge and skills learned in previous course work. Completion of a background check is required prior to commencing the field placement.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Verbal and nonverbal communication with clients

courseDescription: This course provides an opportunity to learn one's personal style for supervision, to have supervised field supervision experiences and to gain an understanding of the different models of supervision.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying areas for improvement in supervision styles
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively during supervision sessions
Setting clear goals and expectations for supervisees
Inspiring and motivating supervisees to enhance their skills

courseTitle: Professional Issues in School Counseling K-12
courseDescription: A professional seminar that emphasizes the contemporary role of the school counselor as leader and advocate in delivering school counseling programs to all students.  Emphasis is placed on acquiring the awareness, knowledge and skills necessary to negotiate the cultural, educational, and contextual forces that impact the lives and academic achievement of students in a pluralistic society.  Twenty hours of observation in a school is required.  Completion of a background check is required prior to commencing the field placement. In addition, students are also required to attend a one-day program on a pre-determined date during the semester.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing digital resources for counseling programs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of cultural influences on academic achievement
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Advocating for student needs at a systemic level

courseTitle: School Culture, Learning, and Classroom Management
courseDescription: School counselor's role in contributing to a safe, equitable, and culturally responsive school culture; promoting student learning and achievement; and the practice of effective teaching and classroom management.  Cultural, political, economic, ethical, and legal issues are addressed.  Ten hours of observation in a school is required. Completion of a background check is required prior to commencing the field placement.
Technical and Digital Skills: Observation skills in a school setting
Utilizing educational technology for classroom management
Understanding legal issues related to education
Conducting background checks for field placements
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Promoting equitable school culture through communication
Collaborating with teachers and staff for effective teaching practices
Engaging with students from diverse backgrounds
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Addressing cultural, political, and ethical issues in education
Analyzing student learning and achievement data for improvement
Implementing solutions for classroom management challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading initiatives for a safe school culture
Coordinating field placements and observation schedules

courseTitle: Counseling Children and Adolescents in School Settings
courseDescription: This course will provide an overview of theories and techniques of counseling children and adolescents in school settings.  Emphasis will be placed upon the counselor's role as a facilitator of normal developmental processes to promote academic success.
Technical and Digital Skills: Counseling techniques for children and adolescents
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Active listening with children and adolescents
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Creating intervention plans for academic challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group counseling sessions in schools
Collaborating with teachers and parents for student support

courseDescription: This course is designed as a capstone experience that synthesizes graduate course work into a practical school counseling program manual.  Emphasis is placed on assessment, data collection and analysis, design and development, implementation and evaluation of systemic school counseling programs K-12.  Specific emphasis is given to the integration of assessed needs, the National Standards for School Counseling Programs and the Virginia Standards of Learning.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Integration of standards into program design
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Alignment with national and state standards

courseDescription: This course will examine the broad range of roles and functions of the mental health counselor within contemporary professional practice settings.
Couples counseling focuses on development of effective counseling skills in working with couples.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying root causes of relationship issues

courseTitle: Diagnosis and Treatment Planning in Mental Health Counseling
courseDescription: A course focused on developing knowledge, attitudes, and skills essential to effective DSM-5 diagnosis, client conceptualization assessment, and clinical treatment planning.   Emphasis on the use of client conceptualization models as a basis for treatment planning in mental health counseling.

Overview of counseling services provided on college and university campuses.  Topics include wellness of students, multicultural issues, ethical and legal issues, crisis and disaster response, advocacy, and program evaluation.

courseTitle: Understanding Military Connected Children and Families
courseDescription: Participants will learn about the unique academic, social, and emotional challenges faced by military connected children and their families.  Participants will review, analyze and practice research-based learning and behavioral strategies and interventions to address these needs.  This course will also introduce effective practices for supporting children through deployment separation, reunion and reintegration, and grief and trauma, including promoting school connectedness, fostering resiliency, facilitating coping skills, and designing customized academic, social, and behavioral supports.  This course is required for completion of the Military Child and Family Education graduate certificate.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing challenges faced by military connected children and families
Designing interventions for grief and trauma
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementing effective practices for reunion and reintegration
Designing behavioral supports for military connected children
Leading efforts to address academic, social, and emotional challenges

courseDescription: The course offers a study of the family as a system, family life cycle stages, tasks, and difficulties that families may experience as they move through their developmental stages.  Concepts and principles applicable to helping people within a systems perspective will also be discussed.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying systems thinking to family issues

courseDescription: The study of selected topics in counseling.
Individualized study under the supervision of a graduate faculty member.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Networking with professionals in the field

courseDescription: Research on a topic or project related to counseling.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis using SPSS or NVivo
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of research findings to stakeholders

courseDescription: Exploration of theories informing practice regarding late adolescent, young adult, and adult psychological and cognitive development, adjustment, and learning in the two- and four- year college and university context.  Influences of individual differences highlighted.  Applications for college counseling, higher education, and community college practitioners, professionals, and leaders.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding theories of psychological and cognitive development in late adolescents and adults
Applying theories to college counseling and higher education contexts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with late adolescent and adult populations
Collaboration with college and university practitioners and professionals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing individual differences in development and learning
Applying theories to real-world scenarios in college and university settings
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in college counseling and higher education settings
Organizational management in community college contexts

courseDescription: An in-depth study of selected counseling theories through the study of cases.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing treatment plans based on theoretical frameworks

courseDescription: Development of group leadership skills through group experiences in class and in the field.

An overview of methods for integrating spirituality into counseling as a means of promoting holistic wellness for both clients and counselors. Emphasis will be placed upon theories of spiritual development, beliefs inherent in major wisdom traditions, implicit and explicit strategies for integrating spirituality into counseling, and the counselor's own personal and professional awareness and growth.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing online resources for spiritual research
Implementing technology for virtual counseling sessions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathy and compassion in counseling sessions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Creating personalized spiritual growth plans for clients
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing multiple spiritual counseling cases efficiently
Leading group counseling sessions with spiritual focus

courseDescription: The study of selected topics in counseling.
Individual study under the supervision of a graduate faculty member.

courseTitle: Current Issues in Counseling and Counselor Education
courseDescription: The course will focus on the current issues in counseling to include the role of ethical and legal considerations in counselor education and supervision, theories and skills in leadership, social and cultural issues to include social change theory and advocacy action planning, and developmental counseling.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of ethical and legal considerations in counseling
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of ethical dilemmas in counseling
Analytical approach to social and cultural issues in counseling
Problem-solving in counselor education and supervision

courseDescription: Exploration of theories informing practice regarding late adolescent, young adult, and adult psychological and cognitive development, adjustment, and learning in the two- and four- year college and university context.  Influences of individual differences highlighted.  Applications for college counseling, higher education, and community college practitioners, professionals, and leaders.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of late adolescent, young adult, and adult psychological and cognitive development
Knowledge of adjustment and learning theories in college and university context
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with late adolescents and young adults
Building rapport with college and university students
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of individual differences in late adolescent and adult development
Applying theories to practical counseling and higher education scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in college counseling and higher education settings
Team management in community college environments

courseTitle: Advanced Counseling Research Design and Assessment
courseDescription: The doctoral-level course examines advanced topics and controversies in qualitative and quantitative counseling research; this integration of theoretical with applied counseling material will augment the department's standard doctoral research offerings.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with peers on research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Designing research studies to address controversies in counseling research

courseDescription: An in-depth study of selected counseling theories through the study of cases.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessment and diagnosis skills in counseling

courseDescription: Development of group leadership skills through group experiences in class and in the field.

This course provides advanced training and skill development in supervision. Specific topics in supervision will also be examined. These include: ethical and legal issues, multicultural competency in supervision; theories of counselor development; theories/models, processes, and skills in supervision.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ethical and legal issues in supervision
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and addressing ethical dilemmas in supervision
Analyzing supervision theories for practical application

courseTitle: Multicultural Perspectives in Counselor Education, Supervision, and Research
courseDescription: Counseling doctoral students will study multicultural issues in counselor preparation graduate programs, counseling supervision, and counseling research.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective supervision techniques in a multicultural context

courseDescription: This internship is designed to provide individual students with a planned program of advanced on-the-job professional experience in a college, school, or community/agency setting. In addition, supervisory and teaching experiences are required. Internship assignments will be controlled and coordinated by a university instructor.  Direct supervision is given by an experienced professional in the setting.  Minimum of 600 hours.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Case formulation based on client data
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team collaboration in a counseling setting

courseDescription: This advanced supervised practicum in counseling experience will enable doctoral-level students to develop and/or refine advanced counseling skills and conceptually link counselor practice and supervision.  Minimum of 200 hours.

courseTitle: Complementary & Alternative Therapies in Mental Health Counseling
courseDescription: The course provides an overview of complementary and alternative therapies being used in mental health today, looking at their effectiveness and safety in treating specific client populations and for use in treating specific disorders, including ADHD, depression, addictions, and anxiety. Modalities covered include acupuncture, nutritional medicine, herbal medicine, biofeedback, meditation, hypnotherapy, aromatherapy, and others.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with clients about alternative therapies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of the effectiveness of different therapies
Tailoring treatment plans for specific disorders based on client needs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing multiple therapy modalities for a client
Providing guidance and leadership in integrating complementary therapies in mental health counseling

courseDescription: An overview of methods for integrating spirituality into counseling as a means of promoting holistic wellness for both clients and counselors. Emphasis will be placed upon theories of spiritual development, beliefs inherent in major wisdom traditions, implicit and explicit strategies for integrating spirituality into counseling, and the counselor's own personal and professional awareness and growth.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing digital tools for spiritual assessments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Active listening to understand client's spiritual beliefs
Effective communication of spiritual concepts with clients
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying conflicts between spiritual beliefs and counseling goals
Developing strategies to address spiritual concerns in counseling sessions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Creating a supportive environment for discussing spirituality in counseling
Leading group discussions on integrating spirituality into therapy

courseDescription: The study of selected topics in counseling.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying underlying issues in client behavior

courseDescription: Individualized study under the supervision of a graduate faculty member.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Networking with professionals in the field

courseDescription: This seminar is designed to assist students in making substantive progress in identifying and developing their dissertation proposal.  Students will critically examine the current literature associated with their research interests and examine applicable conceptual constructs and methodologies.
1-12 credits.

This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation.  All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of their graduation.

This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination.  All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Networking with professionals in the field
